results.title: Exposure
results.creator_credit: Thorold Dickinson and United Nations. Film Board
results.brief_description: A compilation of footage showing the plight of the world’s homeless estimated at 40 million after World War II. Includes pictures of refugee life in the hope of raising international public awareness and support to help the refugees.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Thorold Dickinson and United Nations. Film Board

results.title: Exports flow through Fremantle
results.creator_credit: Les Bambury, Fremantle Port Authority and Supreme Sound Studios
results.brief_description: Shows the export activity of the Port of Fremantle, with the work of all stages of production and processing of grain, fruit, wool and crayfish representing the primary industries of the state.

results.title: Explosives: the two metre lifeline
results.creator_credit: Donald Crombie, David Plummer, Milton Ingerson and South Australian Film Corporation
results.brief_description:
In this 1974 film, the use of comedy and narrative drama are employed to demonstrate the correct handling of explosives and detonators. Produced by the South Australian Film Corporation for the South Australian Mines Department, the film shows three people who handle explosives in the course of an ordinary day: a farmer removing tree stumps from his paddock, an opal miner in Coober Pedy and a ‘powder monkey’ on a road construction crew.

Introduced by a stereotypical ‘Aussie bloke’ drinking a beer at the pub, the film follows the three protagonists through their separate stories, as the narrator points out the mistakes and correct methods in their techniques. Demonstrating a casual, light-hearted approach to safety instruction, this film is a humorous presentation filled with expletives and colloquial terms, aimed to speak to workers on their level.

The colour is faded throughout the film.

Please note: As this is an archival work, the content does not reflect current practice or standards. Professional advice for up-to-date safety practices should be sought from the appropriate contemporary authority.

results.title: Exploring the universe
results.creator_credit: Walter Bartky and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Demonstrates the principle and construction of telescopes. Shows by animation the binaries, trinaries, the variables and why they vary, galaxies and galactic rotation. Shows also what will happen to the Big Dipper in 100,000 years and illustrates the theory of the expanding universe.
results.description: Demonstrates the principle and construction of telescopes. Shows by animation the binaries, trinaries, the variables and why they vary, galaxies and galactic rotation. Shows also what will happen to the Big Dipper in 100,000 years and illustrates the theory of the expanding universe.

results.title: Exploring the ocean
results.brief_description: Points out that although we have charted the ocean’s surface in detail, below the surface lies a part of the world that we are just beginning to explore. Uses animation to picture the ocean’s floor, slopes and continental shelves, and to explain how we explore by sounding and photography. Describes the ocean’s plants and animals and explains how all life in the ocean depends on the tiniest forms of plant life. Discusses the ocean’s vast storehouse of minerals and describes the part played by the water cycle in depositing these minerals.

results.title: Exploring the night sky
results.creator_credit: Milan Herzog and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: A class-room film explaining the nature of stars and constellations and demonstrating the operation of an observatory telescope. Uses animation to identify the characters and shapes associated with constellations, explaining why they appear to be changing positions in the sky. Points out that the distances between stars and planets is not expressed in miles but light years.

results.title: Exploring the human nervous system
results.brief_description: The advances being made in research into the workings of the human nervous system. The nervous system itself is described by means of animated drawings. Also indicates what is being done to understand memory and learning. Compares the nervous systems of the hydra and the earth worm with the complex human nervous system.

results.title: Exploring the atomic nucleus
results.brief_description: Protons and neutrons are now known to be composed of dozens of other particles whose interactions have yet to be accurately described. Physicists are detecting and analysing particle interactions with the aid of particle accelerators, bubble chambers and other sophisticated devices of high energy physics, thus arriving at a fuller understanding of the atomic nucleus.

results.title: Hi daddy (TEFC)
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Exploring Childhood”.
Follows the family of a four-year-old girl through one afternoon showing her mother, father, and her five-year-old brother.

results.title: The Explorer
results.creator_credit: Tim Burstall, Patrick Ryan and Eltham Films
results.brief_description: Albert Tucker (1914-) is an intellectual artist with great independence of mind and mental courage. He has succeeded in fashioning a distinctive style and is now one of the leading artists in Australia. This film is based on a series of paintings by Tucker which deals with an unnamed explorer who perished in the outback desert. Imaginative paintings in an imaginative film.
